Data Manipulation in R & Python

Using dplyr, data.table, and pandas/numpy

One of my favorite posts is the comparison between data.table and the tidyverse’s dplyr packages. Here is the link to that post. I have used that when trying to build my competence in using data.table. Now I’m going to try and expand on that by creating this post that compares cases of using dplyr, data.table, and now pandas. Hopefully this can be as useful as the comparison between dplyr an data.table post was for me. This is not an extensive way of comparing them but just to get started for anyone that wants to use python more.

Packages & Data

library(tidyverse)
library(data.table)

r_data <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(n = 1000),
  x2 = rnorm(n = 1000, sd = 3),
  y = rbinom(n = 1000, size = 1, prob = .6)
)

print(r_data)
# A tibble: 1,000 × 3
        x     x2     y
    <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
 1  1.09  -0.457     1
 2  1.71   2.05      0
 3 -0.363 -1.66      1
 4  1.15  -3.56      1
 5  0.674  0.632     1
 6 -0.651  0.850     0
 7  1.37   3.76      1
 8 -1.61   2.95      0
 9 -1.82  -0.946     1
10  0.446 -1.72      1
# ℹ 990 more rows
r_table <- data.table(
  x = rnorm(n = 1000),
  x2 = rnorm(n = 1000, sd = 3),
  y = rbinom(n = 1000, size = 1, prob = .6)
)

print(r_table)
               x         x2     y
           <num>      <num> <int>
   1:  0.3012969 -0.1892336     1
   2:  1.1449794 -5.2480202     1
   3:  0.6129881  0.5847694     0
   4:  0.6039375  3.4301031     1
   5: -2.8776286 -5.6320773     1
  ---                            
 996: -0.9114861  2.5353439     0
 997:  1.1254929 -3.6333616     0
 998: -0.4209153 -0.8611292     0
 999: -0.8542033 -2.4980987     0
1000: -1.5694783  3.1800399     0
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

data = {
    "x": np.random.normal(0, scale=1, size=1000),
    "x2": np.random.normal(0, scale=3, size=1000),
    "y": np.random.binomial(n=1, p=0.6, size=1000)
}

# Creating DataFrame
py_data = pd.DataFrame(data)

print(py_data)
            x        x2  y
0    1.625495 -2.513493  1
1    1.375477  1.419490  1
2    0.896304  3.582105  0
3    1.279369  3.155540  0
4   -0.992507  2.701708  1
..        ...       ... ..
995 -0.035682  0.624143  1
996 -0.157006 -0.177728  1
997 -1.229564 -2.765229  1
998 -0.736607  0.248886  0
999 -0.070255  0.822051  0

[1000 rows x 3 columns]

Basic Operations

Filtering (Integers)

r_data |>
  filter(
    x > 1
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
      x     x2     y
  <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
1  1.09 -0.457     1
2  1.71  2.05      0
3  1.15 -3.56      1
4  1.37  3.76      1
5  1.30  3.83      1
6  3.01  2.09      0
head(
  r_table[x > 1]
)
          x         x2     y
      <num>      <num> <int>
1: 1.144979 -5.2480202     1
2: 2.284941  5.9637749     0
3: 1.196674 -0.6543321     1
4: 1.890398 -1.8352037     0
5: 1.850590 -1.2532883     1
6: 2.428723  0.2854589     0
py_data[py_data["x"] > 1].head()
           x        x2  y
0   1.625495 -2.513493  1
1   1.375477  1.419490  1
3   1.279369  3.155540  0
5   1.212755  2.003532  0
11  1.412002 -2.758251  1

Filtering (Categorical)

r_data |>
  filter(
    y == 1
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
       x     x2     y
   <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
1  1.09  -0.457     1
2 -0.363 -1.66      1
3  1.15  -3.56      1
4  0.674  0.632     1
5  1.37   3.76      1
6 -1.82  -0.946     1
head(
  r_table[y == 1]
)
            x         x2     y
        <num>      <num> <int>
1:  0.3012969 -0.1892336     1
2:  1.1449794 -5.2480202     1
3:  0.6039375  3.4301031     1
4: -2.8776286 -5.6320773     1
5:  1.1966740 -0.6543321     1
6:  1.8505904 -1.2532883     1
py_data[py_data["y"] == 1].head()
          x        x2  y
0  1.625495 -2.513493  1
1  1.375477  1.419490  1
4 -0.992507  2.701708  1
8 -0.284489 -0.317201  1
9 -0.110960 -0.468932  1

Filtering Multiple Columns

r_data |>
  filter(
    y == 1 &
    x2 < 0
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
       x     x2     y
   <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
1  1.09  -0.457     1
2 -0.363 -1.66      1
3  1.15  -3.56      1
4 -1.82  -0.946     1
5  0.446 -1.72      1
6 -0.369 -6.86      1
head(
  r_table[
    y == 1 &
    x2 > 0
  ]
)
            x        x2     y
        <num>     <num> <int>
1:  0.6039375 3.4301031     1
2: -0.6132135 2.1888315     1
3: -2.4182992 1.5879010     1
4: -2.0788204 0.6814116     1
5:  0.2546547 0.1272056     1
6:  2.0922497 4.6317957     1
py_data[
  (py_data["y"] == 1) & 
  (py_data["x2"] > 0)
    ].head()
           x        x2  y
1   1.375477  1.419490  1
4  -0.992507  2.701708  1
10 -0.404824  0.780289  1
14  0.237784  2.241245  1
23  0.490488  0.160291  1

Sorting Rows

r_data |> 
  arrange(y) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 3
       x     x2     y
   <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
1  1.71   2.05      0
2 -0.651  0.850     0
3 -1.61   2.95      0
4  0.196 -4.13      0
5  3.01   2.09      0
6  0.228  0.598     0
head(
  r_table[order(y)]
)
            x         x2     y
        <num>      <num> <int>

2:  2.2849412  5.9637749     0

5:  1.8903981 -1.8352037     0
6: -0.9942675  0.1554529     0
py_data.sort_values(by = "y").head()

Selecting Specific Columns

r_data |>
  select(
    y
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 1
      y
  <int>
1     1
2     0
3     1
4     1
5     1
6     0
head(
  r_table[,"y"]
)
       y
   <int>
1:     1
2:     1
3:     0
4:     1
5:     1
6:     0
py_data["y"].head()
0    1
1    1
2    0
3    0
4    1
Name: y, dtype: int32

# py_data.filter(items = "y").head()

Selecting Multiple Columns

r_data |> 
  select(x, x2) |> 
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 2
       x     x2
   <dbl>  <dbl>
1  1.09  -0.457
2  1.71   2.05 
3 -0.363 -1.66 
4  1.15  -3.56 
5  0.674  0.632
6 -0.651  0.850
head(
  r_table[,list(x, x2)]
)
            x         x2
        <num>      <num>
1:  0.3012969 -0.1892336
2:  1.1449794 -5.2480202
3:  0.6129881  0.5847694
4:  0.6039375  3.4301031
5: -2.8776286 -5.6320773
6:  2.2849412  5.9637749
# py_data[{"x", "x2"}].head()

py_data.filter(items = ["x", "x2"]).head()
          x        x2
0  1.625495 -2.513493
1  1.375477  1.419490
2  0.896304  3.582105
3  1.279369  3.155540
4 -0.992507  2.701708

Selecting Using Regex

r_data |>
  select(
    matches("x")
  ) |>
  head()
# A tibble: 6 × 2
       x     x2
   <dbl>  <dbl>
1  1.09  -0.457
2  1.71   2.05 
3 -0.363 -1.66 
4  1.15  -3.56 
5  0.674  0.632
6 -0.651  0.850
cols <- grep("^x", names(r_table))

head(
  r_table[, ..cols]
)
            x         x2
        <num>      <num>
1:  0.3012969 -0.1892336
2:  1.1449794 -5.2480202
3:  0.6129881  0.5847694
4:  0.6039375  3.4301031
5: -2.8776286 -5.6320773
6:  2.2849412  5.9637749
py_data.filter(regex = "x").head()
          x        x2
0  1.625495 -2.513493
1  1.375477  1.419490
2  0.896304  3.582105
3  1.279369  3.155540
4 -0.992507  2.701708

Summarize Data

r_data |>
  summarize(
    avg = mean(x)
  )
# A tibble: 1 × 1
     avg
   <dbl>
1 0.0279
  r_data |>
  summarize(
    total = sum(x)
  )
# A tibble: 1 × 1
  total
  <dbl>
1  27.9
r_table[, .(avg = mean(x))]
           avg
         <num>
1: -0.01425028
r_table[, .(total = sum(x))]
       total
       <num>
1: -14.25028
py_data["x"].mean()
0.002775922653748875
py_data["x"].sum()
2.775922653748875

Adding/Updating/Deleting Columns

r_data <- r_data |>
  mutate(
    x_mult = x*x2
  )
head(r_data)
# A tibble: 6 × 4
       x     x2     y x_mult
   <dbl>  <dbl> <int>  <dbl>
1  1.09  -0.457     1 -0.500
2  1.71   2.05      0  3.49 
3 -0.363 -1.66      1  0.604
4  1.15  -3.56      1 -4.10 
5  0.674  0.632     1  0.426
6 -0.651  0.850     0 -0.554
r_table[, x_mult := x*x2]
head(r_table[, "x_mult"])
        x_mult
         <num>
1: -0.05701551
2: -6.00887504
3:  0.35845670
4:  2.07156775
5: 16.20702631
6: 13.62687485
py_data["x_mult"] = py_data["x"] * py_data["x2"]
py_data["x_mult"].head()
0   -4.085671
1    1.952477
2    3.210656
3    4.037102
4   -2.681463
Name: x_mult, dtype: float64

Counting

r_data |> count(y)
# A tibble: 2 × 2
      y     n
  <int> <int>
1     0   383
2     1   617
r_table[, .N, by = (y)]
       y     N
   <int> <int>
1:     1   619
2:     0   381
py_data["y"].value_counts()
y
1    590
0    410
Name: count, dtype: int64

Group By

r_data |>
  group_by(y) |>
  summarize(
    avg = mean(x)
  )
# A tibble: 2 × 2
      y     avg
  <int>   <dbl>
1     0 0.0599 
2     1 0.00810
r_table[, .(avg = mean(x)), by = "y"]
       y          avg
   <int>        <num>
1:     1 -0.009975402
2:     0 -0.021195561
py_data.groupby("y")[["x"]].mean()
          x
y          
0  0.041513
1 -0.024143

Chain Expressions

r_data |>
  group_by(y) |>
  summarize(
    avg = mean(x)
  ) |>
  filter(
    y == 1
  )
# A tibble: 1 × 2
      y     avg
  <int>   <dbl>
1     1 0.00810
r_table[, 
  by = y,
  .(avg = mean(x))
  ][
    y == 1
  ]
       y          avg
   <int>        <num>
1:     1 -0.009975402
py_group = py_data.groupby("y")[["x"]].mean()

py_group.loc[1]
x   -0.024143
Name: 1, dtype: float64

Pivot Data

r_data |>
  pivot_longer(
    -y
  )
# A tibble: 3,000 × 3
       y name    value
   <int> <chr>   <dbl>
 1     1 x       1.09 
 2     1 x2     -0.457
 3     1 x_mult -0.500
 4     0 x       1.71 
 5     0 x2      2.05 
 6     0 x_mult  3.49 
 7     1 x      -0.363
 8     1 x2     -1.66 
 9     1 x_mult  0.604
10     1 x       1.15 
# ℹ 2,990 more rows
melt(r_table, id.vars = "y")
          y variable      value
      <int>   <fctr>      <num>
   1:     1        x  0.3012969
   2:     1        x  1.1449794
   3:     0        x  0.6129881
   4:     1        x  0.6039375
   5:     1        x -2.8776286
  ---                          
2996:     0   x_mult -2.3109308
2997:     0   x_mult -4.0893226
2998:     0   x_mult  0.3624624
2999:     0   x_mult  2.1338842
3000:     0   x_mult -4.9910036
py_data["id"] = py_data.index

py_data.head()
          x        x2  y    x_mult  id
0  1.625495 -2.513493  1 -4.085671   0
1  1.375477  1.419490  1  1.952477   1
2  0.896304  3.582105  0  3.210656   2
3  1.279369  3.155540  0  4.037102   3
4 -0.992507  2.701708  1 -2.681463   4
py_pivot = py_data.pivot(index='id', columns='y', values=['x', 'x2', 'x_mult'])

print(py_pivot.head())
           x                  x2              x_mult          
y          0         1         0         1         0         1
id                                                            
0        NaN  1.625495       NaN -2.513493       NaN -4.085671
1        NaN  1.375477       NaN  1.419490       NaN  1.952477
2   0.896304       NaN  3.582105       NaN  3.210656       NaN
3   1.279369       NaN  3.155540       NaN  4.037102       NaN
4        NaN -0.992507       NaN  2.701708       NaN -2.681463
